text: I've now got a kind of crazy histogram function that can sort of handle dates and missings, and switch to a barplot for small discrete sets. Is there an upstream place where it would be helpful put something like this? It's a bit opinionated. Also, any ideas about how to make the `missing` column better?

elements.text: I've now got a kind of crazy histogram function that can sort of handle dates and missings, and switch to a barplot for small discrete sets. Is there an upstream place where it would be helpful put something like this? It's a bit opinionated. Also, any ideas about how to make the

text:
```###
### Plotting code
###

using StatsBase, AbstractPlotting, Dates

"""
    countplot!(ax, things_to_count)

Creates a barplot in `ax` to mimic
a histogram of a small discrete set.
"""
function countplot!(ax, things_to_count)
    d = countmap(things_to_count)
    xs = collect(keys(d))
    ys = collect(values(d))
    m, M = extrema(xs)
    ax.xticks = (m:M, string.(m:M))
    return barplot!(ax, xs, ys; width=1)
end

"""
    unvalue(::Type{T}, i::Int)

Attempts to reconstruct a Dates type by inverting `Dates.value(obj::T)`.
"""
unvalue(::Type{T}, i::Int) where {T} = T(i)
unvalue(::Type{Date}, i::Int) = Date(Dates.UTInstant{Day}(Day(i)))

"""
    treat_as_discrete(things_to_count; max_ints = 25) -> Bool

Heuristically decide if we should treat `things_to_count` as a
discrete set or a continuous set.
"""
function treat_as_discrete(things_to_count; max_ints=25)
    nonmissingtype(eltype(things_to_count)) <: Union{Integer,Symbol,String} || return false
    if nonmissingtype(eltype(things_to_count)) <: Integer
        m, M = extrema(things_to_count)
        M - m <= max_ints || return false
    end
    return true
end

"""
    handle_dates!(ax, values) -> values′

If `values` contains Date types we can handle,
then return integer versions of them and update
the axis formatter to label them correctly.
"""
function handle_dates!(ax, values)
    T = nonmissingtype(eltype(values))
    if T <: Dates.Date || T <: Day
        values = Dates.value.(values)
        ax.xtickformat[] = (s -> string.(unvalue.(T, round.(Int, s))))
    end
    return values
end

"""
    plot_hist(things_to_count, xlabel=nothing, ylabel=nothing; discrete = nothing)

Plot a "histogram" for vectors that can contain `missing`, and could have dates
or be a discrete set.
"""
function plot_hist(things_to_count, xlabel=nothing, ylabel=nothing; discrete=nothing,
                  title=nothing)
    n_missing = count(ismissing, things_to_count)
    things_to_count = filter(!ismissing, things_to_count)

    fig = Figure()

    ax = fig[1, 1] = title === nothing ? Axis(fig) : Axis(fig; title)

    xlabel !== nothing && (ax.xlabel = xlabel)
    ylabel !== nothing && (ax.ylabel = ylabel)

    things_to_count = handle_dates!(ax, things_to_count)

    discrete === nothing && (discrete = treat_as_discrete(things_to_count))

    discrete ? countplot!(ax, things_to_count) : hist!(ax, things_to_count)

    # some crazy code to try to hack in a `missing` bar at the end
    if n_missing > 0
        fig.layout.default_colgap = AbstractPlotting.GridLayoutBase.Fixed(0.0)

        ax.rightspinevisible = false
        ax_missing = fig[1, 2] = Axis(fig)
        ax_missing.leftspinevisible = false
        b = barplot!(ax_missing, [Point2f0(0, n_missing)]; width=[3])

        ax_missing.targetlimits = BBox(-6, 2, 0, 100)

        ax_missing.xticks = ([0], ["missing"])
        ax_missing.width = 100
        hideydecorations!(ax_missing; grid=false)
        linkyaxes!(ax, ax_missing)
    end
    return fig
end

###
### Examples
###

using CairoMakie

vals = [rand() < 0.1 ? missing : Date(rand(1900:2000), rand(1:12), rand(1:28))
        for _ in 1:100]
fig = plot_hist(vals, "Dates", "Counts"; title="Dates")
CairoMakie.save("dates.png", fig)

vals = [Day(rand(1:100)) for _ in 1:100]
fig = plot_hist(vals; title="Days")
CairoMakie.save("days.png", fig)

small_counts = [rand(1:10, 100); missing]
fig = plot_hist(small_counts; title="Small counts")
CairoMakie.save("small_counts.png", fig)

large_counts = [rand(1:50, 100); missing]
fig = plot_hist(large_counts; title="Large counts")
CairoMakie.save("large_counts.png", fig)```

###
### Plotting code
###

using StatsBase, AbstractPlotting, Dates

"""
    countplot!(ax, things_to_count)

Creates a barplot in `ax` to mimic
a histogram of a small discrete set.
"""
function countplot!(ax, things_to_count)
    d = countmap(things_to_count)
    xs = collect(keys(d))
    ys = collect(values(d))
    m, M = extrema(xs)
    ax.xticks = (m:M, string.(m:M))
    return barplot!(ax, xs, ys; width=1)
end

"""
    unvalue(::Type{T}, i::Int)

Attempts to reconstruct a Dates type by inverting `Dates.value(obj::T)`.
"""
unvalue(::Type{T}, i::Int) where {T} = T(i)
unvalue(::Type{Date}, i::Int) = Date(Dates.UTInstant{Day}(Day(i)))

"""
    treat_as_discrete(things_to_count; max_ints = 25) -> Bool

Heuristically decide if we should treat `things_to_count` as a
discrete set or a continuous set.
"""
function treat_as_discrete(things_to_count; max_ints=25)
    nonmissingtype(eltype(things_to_count)) <: Union{Integer,Symbol,String} || return false
    if nonmissingtype(eltype(things_to_count)) <: Integer
        m, M = extrema(things_to_count)
        M - m <= max_ints || return false
    end
    return true
end

"""
    handle_dates!(ax, values) -> values′

If `values` contains Date types we can handle,
then return integer versions of them and update
the axis formatter to label them correctly.
"""
function handle_dates!(ax, values)
    T = nonmissingtype(eltype(values))
    if T <: Dates.Date || T <: Day
        values = Dates.value.(values)
        ax.xtickformat[] = (s -> string.(unvalue.(T, round.(Int, s))))
    end
    return values
end

"""
    plot_hist(things_to_count, xlabel=nothing, ylabel=nothing; discrete = nothing)

Plot a "histogram" for vectors that can contain `missing`, and could have dates
or be a discrete set.
"""
function plot_hist(things_to_count, xlabel=nothing, ylabel=nothing; discrete=nothing,
                  title=nothing)
    n_missing = count(ismissing, things_to_count)
    things_to_count = filter(!ismissing, things_to_count)

    fig = Figure()

    ax = fig[1, 1] = title === nothing ? Axis(fig) : Axis(fig; title)

    xlabel !== nothing && (ax.xlabel = xlabel)
    ylabel !== nothing && (ax.ylabel = ylabel)

    things_to_count = handle_dates!(ax, things_to_count)

    discrete === nothing && (discrete = treat_as_discrete(things_to_count))

    discrete ? countplot!(ax, things_to_count) : hist!(ax, things_to_count)

    # some crazy code to try to hack in a `missing` bar at the end
    if n_missing > 0
        fig.layout.default_colgap = AbstractPlotting.GridLayoutBase.Fixed(0.0)

        ax.rightspinevisible = false
        ax_missing = fig[1, 2] = Axis(fig)
        ax_missing.leftspinevisible = false
        b = barplot!(ax_missing, [Point2f0(0, n_missing)]; width=[3])

        ax_missing.targetlimits = BBox(-6, 2, 0, 100)

        ax_missing.xticks = ([0], ["missing"])
        ax_missing.width = 100
        hideydecorations!(ax_missing; grid=false)
        linkyaxes!(ax, ax_missing)
    end
    return fig
end

###
### Examples
###

using CairoMakie

vals = [rand() < 0.1 ? missing : Date(rand(1900:2000), rand(1:12), rand(1:28))
        for _ in 1:100]
fig = plot_hist(vals, "Dates", "Counts"; title="Dates")
CairoMakie.save("dates.png", fig)

vals = [Day(rand(1:100)) for _ in 1:100]
fig = plot_hist(vals; title="Days")
CairoMakie.save("days.png", fig)

small_counts = [rand(1:10, 100); missing]
fig = plot_hist(small_counts; title="Small counts")
CairoMakie.save("small_counts.png", fig)

large_counts = [rand(1:50, 100); missing]
fig = plot_hist(large_counts; title="Large counts")
CairoMakie.save("large_counts.png", fig)

text: What about a missing datum as `(Date(1,1,1), missing)`? Then the indication of a missing data point should be in the relevant column

elements.text: What about a missing datum as
? Then the indication of a missing data point should be in the relevant column

text:
like if you have a bunch dates and each has a variable you're counting the frequencies of, and if some of those variables are missing, they are missing at specific dates. And then those datwes, where ever they may fall bin-wise, those should therefore show at that bin.

OR

the situation is that you have a bunch of dates and their corresponding variables you count, and then separately, you have a bunch of missing pairs of date-variables. So you know someone measured the variable at some date but you don't know when and what the result was. That would look more like what you plotted.

text:
ah, I see, like plotting a timeseries. For my use, the dates *are* the data; for the thing I'm working on right now, they are birthdates, and so the histogram is showing the distribution of birthdates.

I think what you're describing wouldn't really be a histogram, because it's not just counting things, since you have a pair of values

text: ah actually I think what you're describing is a weighted histogram maybe? where each point has a weight, and what I have is with each weight being 1 (so it's just a count)

text: Ah, I understand, ok. I now realize I was thinking of interval trees, but missing weights is a whole other thing. Cool!
